title: 7 in 10 parents admit to sending sick kids to school, but they have 3 good reasons why
text:
Once back-to-school/cold and flu season rolls around, parents like Alexandra Fung brace for wintry bugs to make themselves at home until the spring.

“Unfortunately, our kids seem to be sick with some kind of bug most or all of the winter,” said Fung, 38, who has three kids ages two, 10 and 12 — as well as a fourth on the way — in Chicago.

So she and many families are faced with the persistent dilemma of whether that runny nose, cough or bellyache means that their kid is too sick to go to class. In fact, seven in 10 parents confess to sometimes sending their child to school, even when they know that they are ill, according to a recent poll by British health and hygiene company Essity. Worse, more than a third of the 2,000 surveyed moms and dads with kids ages 3 to 16 believe that a bug has spread around school as a result of their kid showing up sick.

“We can’t keep the kids home anytime they’re sniffly or coughing, or they wouldn’t be at school at all,” said Fung, the CEO of Upparent, a recommendation-sharing site for parents. She told MarketWatch that she does always keep them home if they’ve been vomiting or have a fever, however.

Randy Hayashi, the COO of payment processing company Payment Depot, also shared that he’s sent his sixth grader and high school freshman in “kind of sick” at times. “It is really hard not to do it,” he said. “In fact every year at the end of the school year, when that small handful of kids get their perfect attendance award, I chuckle to myself thinking, ‘Congratulations, you went to school while sick more than any other kid.’”

In fact, most of the parents surveyed by Essity (70%) said that their child has come to school with a cold. And even pediatricians like Dr. Sara Siddiqui from NYU Langone’s Hassenfeld Children’s Hospital say that’s OK — within reason.

“If we kept everyone home for some nasal congestion and cough, your kids would be home the whole entire fall season,” she said. “Having a fever [100.4 degrees Fahrenheit for kids under two months old, and 101 and up for everyone else] is the part that indicates whether they are contagious or not.” Kids should stay home from school until they’ve gone 24 hours without a fever — and while off of fever reducers like Johnson & Johnson’s JNJ, -0.68% Tylenol or Pfizer’s PFE, +0.39% Advil. They should also stay home for 24 hours after vomiting, or if they have recurring diarrhea twice a day or more, she said.

STUDIOGRANDOUEST/iStock Most parents have sent a little one feeling under the weather to school. Here’s why.

Yet around one in five surveyed parents revealed they had sent their child to school with an ear infection (22%) or with a viral infection (19%). Seventeen percent confessed their kids came to school with diarrhea or vomiting — and 14% said they sent their kid in with the chicken pox before the spots fully scabbed over and stopped being contagious. Worse, almost one in four admitted they schooled their young scholar to lie about their health to stay in school.

Erin Reeder, a mother of four girls ages two to seven, recognizes the struggle for both parents and schools: she’s an adjunct history professor, and her husband is a school psychologist in Gilbert, Ariz. “We’re acutely aware of how frustrating it can be when sick kids spread illness throughout the student body,” she told MarketWatch. “But on the other hand, as two working parents, we know how hard it can be to find alternate arrangements for sick kids.”

She admitted that she’s sometimes sent one of the girls back to class without waiting for them to be fever-free for a full 24 hours, as doctors recommend, but otherwise she and her husband have learned to methodically run through the ailing child’s symptoms to determine if they are contagiously sick, or if that scratchy throat could be allergies, or that tummy ache is stress. “We’ve found that our intuition has been pretty ‘on’ in this department,” she said. “When we’ve sent complaining kids to school, they’ve always ended up not really being sick.”

The parents that MarketWatch spoke with said that they didn’t want to contribute to germs already running rampant in many daycares and public schools. But similar to the moms and dads in the Essity study, they’re often caught juggling work, parenting and financial responsibilities.

“The struggle is real,” said Reeder, who also blogs at The Incremental Mama. She and her husband often have to piecemeal a caregiving strategy together, such as him working from home and taking conference calls while caring for their child in the morning, until Reeder can take over once her classes are done after lunch. “Every time is a little different for us,” she said. “It’s often deciding, for which one of you will it be the least painful to miss work today?”

So what are the major reasons that parents get stuck sending sick kids to school?

Work Stress

Most parents in the Essity survey blamed work pressure for not keeping their children home. Almost one in three said they couldn’t afford to miss any more time on the job, and more than one in five worried about what their co-workers would think of them if they stayed home to care for their children.

Parents just don’t have workplace flexibility: Only 15% of American private sector workers get paid leave, according to the U.S. Department of Labor.

Related: The real reason companies like Target are offering paid parental leave and child-care

And those lucky enough to have paid sick days only have about 11 on average if they are full-time workers, and seven if they’re part-time. One bad cold can last seven to 10 days, and it’s normal for kids to catch six to 10 colds a year. Even shorter stomach bugs or cases of pinkeye that run for a few days apiece add up fast. And that gets into school attendance requirements.

Fung noted that kids in her school district are considered truant after they’ve missed nine or 10 days of school in a semester. And considering her three kids often pass colds and other bugs around and around, “those two or three days at a time add up,” she said. “So another factor we consider when deciding whether our child should stay home is, ‘Well, if they’re just a little sick and not contagious, and they can probably pay attention and engage, then let’s not keep them home that 10th day.’”

Childcare costs

Many parents who can’t afford to miss work also can’t afford to pay someone to watch their sick kids.

Childcare costs have shot up to almost $10,000 a year for just one child’s day care, and babysitters command upwards of $16 an hour. While the Department of Health and Human Services says that families shouldn’t spend more than 7% of their income on child care, there’s not a single state in America where parents can stick to that budget.

Related: Child-care costs in America have soared to nearly $10K per year

“Our saving grace is flexibility with work,” said Reeder. Fung is also fortunate to be able to work from home, as well as having family nearby who can watch the kids in a pinch.

But many parents aren’t so fortunate. This single mom from South Carolina told MarketWatch that she has seen her income shrink from $15 an hour to $9 thanks to daycare costs. Almost 2 million parents with kids ages five and younger had to quit their job, refuse an offer or switch jobs in 2016 because of child care issues.

Related: How a lack of good, inexpensive day care rocked one woman’s career

A cademic pressure

In some cases, the kids themselves insist on going to school even when they’re not feeling well. A quarter of parents in the Essity report said they sent their sick kid to class because the child didn’t want to miss something important like a field trip.

Hayashi said his kids “want nothing to do with a sick day from school,” because junior high and high school has become so competitive. Indeed, a recent Office Depot survey ODP, -0.60% found that almost one in four parents think their children get more homework than they can handle. A 2015 study published in the American Journal for Family Therapy found that primary school children receive about three times the amount of homework recommended by the National Education Association.

“They feel like if they miss a day or two, they will fall behind and it will be hard to catch up,” said Hayashi. “They will only agree to stay home when they are feeling so bad that there is no way to send them. Times have changed since we were kids and tried to miss school and have a ‘Ferris Bueller’ day.”
description: Work and school pressures are to blame, moms and dads tell MarketWatch
